an10.34:1.1: “Sir, how many qualities should a mendicant have to give ordination?”
an10.34:1.2: “Upāli, a mendicant should have ten qualities to give ordination.
an10.34:1.4: It’s when a mendicant is ethical, restrained in the monastic code, conducting themselves well and seeking alms in suitable places. Seeing danger in the slightest fault, they keep the rules they’ve undertaken.
an10.34:1.5: They’re very learned, remembering and keeping what they’ve learned. These teachings are good in the beginning, good in the middle, and good in the end, meaningful and well-phrased, describing a spiritual practice that’s entirely full and pure. They are very learned in such teachings, remembering them, reinforcing them by recitation, mentally scrutinizing them, and comprehending them theoretically.
an10.34:1.6: Both monastic codes have been passed down to them in detail, well analyzed, well mastered, well judged in both the rules and accompanying material.
an10.34:1.7: They’re able to care for the sick or get someone else to do so.
an10.34:1.8: They’re able to settle dissatisfaction or get someone else to do so.
an10.34:1.9: They’re able to dispel remorse when it has come up.
an10.34:1.10: They’re able to rationally dissuade someone from misconceptions that come up.
an10.34:1.11: They’re able to encourage someone in the higher ethics,
an10.34:1.14: A mendicant should have these ten qualities to give ordination.”
